Clinical_Features.text:
Assess general appearance and behavior
Evaluate volume status
Abdominal and genitourinary examinations are important for potential surgical causes

Pediatric_signs_of_dehydration.text:
Significantly dehydrated if has 2 or more of the following (LR+ 6.1, CI:3.8-9.8):
[1]
Prolonged capillary refill (>2 sec)
Dry mucous membranes
Absence of tears
Abnormal overall appearance
Sunken fontanelle in an infant

Management.text:
Largely depends on etiology
If ill appearing, establish rapid IV access, or if needed IO.
Rapid finger stick blood sugar
Point of care pH and electrolytes (iSTAT)

Pediatric_acute_gastroenteritis_treatmen.text:
Oral rehydration therapy
Avoid IV fluids before doing a trial of oral rehydration therapy in uncomplicated cases of mild to moderate dehydration in children.
[2]
If fails, oral
ondansetron
as a single dose PO (>6 months of age)
[3]
[4]
If fails, IV fluids (e.g.
normal saline
)
Probiotics have NOT been shown to provide any benefit
[5]
